title.narrative: 1.2.1 Capacity support - technical organizational development and leadership development to community organizations

description.narrative: 1.2.1 To enable marginalized young girls, including, LBT*people to develop self confidence and learn new skills to confront violence

comment.narrative: UHAI has a deep body of work and our activities have a long history. This project is useful to continue the work and venture into new phases for these activities. Therefore, it is complex and difficult to assign a baseline to it.
In Quarter 1 we made four grants amounting to USD 50,800-- 4 peer grants, contracted in quarter 1 but decided on by the PGC at the end of 2018. I

In this reporting period, we made six grants to two grants amounting to USD 21,600--a capacity support grant made in Quarter 2 and a Peer grant decided on by the PGC at the end of 2018 but contracted in Quarter 2.
In this reporting period, we made three grants to three organisations amounting to USD 25,694. Two of which were capacity support grants and one strategic grant. -

This number comprises support through our Capacity Support grants and Opportunity Grants portfolios two three organisations in Kenya and Tanzania (BHESP and KSIWA in Kenya, and Women With Ambition (WWA) in Tanzania). They are serialised in our system as CP-0052, OP-123, and OP-0124. grants are reported for using the time of their contracting as proxy but the work will go on through 2020

title.narrative: 1.2 Number of grants, activists/organisations and amount disbursed
1.2.2 Number of organisations/interest groups resourced to support their constituencies

comment.narrative: UHAI has a deep body of work and our activities have a long history. This project is useful to continue the work and venture into new phases for these activities. Therefore, it is complex and difficult to assign a baseline to it.

In Quarter 1 we made four grants amounting to USD 50,800-- 4 peer grants, contracted in quarter 1 but decided on by the PGC at the end of 2018. In total we have made a total of 6 grants amounting to USD 72,400 to LBQ women trans and sex worker groups in Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania.

In this reporting period, we made 2 grants to two grants amounting to USD 21,600--a capacity support grant made in Quarter 2 and a Peer grant decided on by the PGC at the end of 2018 but contracted in Quarter 2.
In this reporting period, we made three grants to three organisations amounting to USD 25,694. Two of which were capacity support grants and one strategic grant.

These include grants made as capacity strengthening and opportunity grants namely ;CP-0052 , OP-0124 and OP-0123 made to sex worker led organisations in Kenya and Tanzania.Bringing the total amount in grant dollars invested in 2019 to $190,257

title.narrative: 1.2.1 Number of women and girls that have increased capability to demand their rights and respond to violence. Details of this capability to be further detailed by consortium partners, possibly categorised into (a) awareness of laws and redressal mechanisms; (b) access to support groups at the community level, and (c) knowledge of various forms of violence.

comment.narrative: UHAI has a deep body of work and our activities have a long history. This project is useful to continue the work and venture into new phases for these activities. Therefore, it is complex and difficult to assign a baseline to it.

This number is as a result of one strategic grant to an LBQ and sex worker organisation in the rural Northern post-conflict region of Uganda, and three peer grants whose work started in 2018 but ended in 2018, and this included support to a female sex worker organisation organising in an informal urban settlement in Western Kenya, support to another trans and female sex worker organisations organising in another informal urban settlement in the capital city of Kampala, and support to a female sex worker organisation in the peri-urban town of Nakuru notorious for female sex worker violence and murders that often used to go unpunished and often encouraged by police unresponsiveness.

With this support Women with Ambition was able to facilitate training for 30 sex workers on issues of advocacy, law, online safety and security, as well as safety at work place and home leading to increased awareness on mechanisms of assessing risks likely to cause violence in relation their work. Strategies for challenging violence towards sex workers were derived. Support to BHESP in Kenya to engage with ICASA 2019 raised their capacity in programming that is inclusive of violence prevention among Trans women sex workers. Targeted interventions were set aside by the organisation for the community. Support to KISWA created awareness on the violence redress mechanisms for sex workers through 3 community meetings and on community radio.

"This number is as a result of two grants- a capacity support grant to an LBQ group in Thika town (59 reached) and a peer grant to a female sex worker group in Zanzibar (350 reached). In Thika, 20 LBQ women were targeted with paralegal training to become community first responders to violence, 5 involved in the mapping of violence hot spots for LBQ women in Thika, 20 engaged in membership meetings on intimate partner violence, 10 in conversation on health sensitization as affects the violence dynamic, and 4 who are staff members of the group targeted with trainings to strengthen their group's institutional capacity to programme around violence with a focus on monitoring and evaluation. Support to a Tanzanian organisation through our peer grant built the capacity of 389 female sex workers on matters legal, health and entrepreneurship as a way of shifting their violence dynamic. through building their negotiating power, and agency in negotiating access to justice and a better appreciation of their health needs."

title.narrative: 1 - Strengthened voices and more connected communities of ALL women so that they can challenge norms, values and power structures and push back against violence against them
O1.1 Number of activists that improved their capabilities in campaigning, public education and awareness raising on VAW and implementing programmes to address VAW developed by implementing partners

comment.narrative: UHAI has a deep body of work and our activities have a long history. This project is useful to continue the work and venture into new phases for these activities. Therefore, it is complex and difficult to assign a baseline to it.
This number includes female sex workers in Uganda and Kenya that reached through support via 4 peer (activist determined) grants made and made in the first quarter.

"This number is as a result of two grants- a capacity support grant to an LBQ group in Thika town (59 reached) and a peer grant to a female sex worker group in Zanzibar (350 reached). In Thika, 20 LBQ women were targeted with paralegal training to become community first responders to violence, 5 involved in the mapping of violence hot spots for LBQ women in Thika, 20 engaged in membership meetings on intimate partner violence, 10 in conversation on health sensitization as affects the violence dynamic, and 4 who are staff members of the group targeted with trainings to strengthen their group's institutional capacity to programme around violence with a focus on monitoring and evaluation. Support to YOSOA through our peer grant built the capacity of 389 female sex workers on matters legal, health and entrepreneurship as a way of shifting their violence dynamic. through building their negotiating power, and agency in negotiating access to justice and a better appreciation of their health needs.

title.narrative: O1.2 Number of strategies /action plans developed to respond to violence

comment.narrative: Through the grantmaking support we gave, three organisations where able to come up with varied plans at different levels of sophistiction and in response tto their institutional gaps. A tanzanian based sex worker organisation implemented various responses to state and non state sanctioned violence such as relocating their offices and training sex workers on violence response.A Kenyan LBQ organisation also built the capacity and awareness of LBQ women in peri urban Kenya to identify and document violence.A second sex worker led organisation was supported to engage and lobby mainstream organisations and funders with a focus on highlighting the experiences of violence faced by marginalised women and the need for supported push back and collaboration against perpetrators.

Through the grantmaking support we gave, three organisations where able to come up with varied plans at different levels of sophistiction and in response tto their institutional gaps. HRI, an LBQ organisation in the post conflict region of Northern Uganda had a gap around capturing their Monitoring and Evaluation data on GBV both in terms of collecting data on a very personal subject, analysing it, and using it to make sense to their programme and hence part of their grant support went around developing a monitoring and evaluation frame work on the monitoring and evaluation of GBV among their constituency. Other organisations and plan include Smart ladies a female sex worker group in the sex work violence endemic country of Nakuru who came up with a strategic plan, and WOPEIN a trans and female sex worker group in tthe informal urban settlement of Bwaise in Kampala, Uganda.

Through the support through grants made to 3 sex worker led organisations in Kenya and Tanzania. 30 sex workers were empowered with capacity and knowledge on advocacy, law, online safety and security, as well as safety at work place and home leading to increase awareness on mechanisms of assessing and mitigating risks of or actual violence in relation to their work. A sex worker led organisation from Kenya engaged and participated in a crucial advocacy platform that is ICASA 2019.In so doing they strengthened their capacity for collaborative collective advocacy that raised their capacity in programming that is inclusive of violence prevention among Trans women sex workers. Support to another Kenyan sex worker led organisation facilitated the enhanced capacity of Kenyan sex workers to respond to violence using existing violence redress mechanisms.
